title: Corneal Defects, Abrasions and Foreign Bodies
author: Magdalena Popiela
keyPoints: Corneal abrasions are superficial losses of corneal epithelium, which heal quickly
They usually occur as result of mechanical trauma, so don't forget to look for other signs of blunt or penetrating eye injury
Fluorescein 2% is useful in diagnosis as it stains the epithelial defect
Corneal foreign bodies should be removed to allow for healing
redFlags: Contact lens wearer with corneal ulcer (Acanthamoeba risk)

q1.text: Is there a visible foreign body on the cornea or conjunctiva?

q2.text: What type of foreign body and how embedded?

q3.text: Any signs of penetration (shallow anterior chamber, iris damage)?

answers.text: No penetration - embedded in cornea only

q4.text: Does fluorescein staining show an epithelial defect?

q5.text: What is the size and depth of the defect?

q6.text: Any history of contact lens wear?

q7.text: Any signs of infection (infiltrate, hypopyon, purulent discharge)?

answers.text: Mild discomfort or foreign body sensation

q9.text: Any recurrent episodes or family history?

penetrating_injury.text: PENETRATING INJURY: Do not remove FB. Eye shield, NBM, urgent ophthalmology referral for surgical removal. Tetanus prophylaxis. IV antibiotics if high infection risk.

embedded_fb.text: EMBEDDED CORNEAL FB: Topical anaesthetic, attempt removal with needle/forceps if superficial. If unsuccessful, urgent ophthalmology referral. Topical antibiotic after removal.

superficial_fb.text: SUPERFICIAL FB: Remove with cotton bud or irrigation. Check for residual material. Topical antibiotic (chloramphenicol QDS). Follow-up in 24-48 hours.

organic_fb.text: ORGANIC FB: High infection risk. Remove if superficial, urgent ophthalmology if embedded. Intensive topical antibiotics. Close follow-up for infection.

large_abrasion.text: LARGE CORNEAL ABRASION: Topical antibiotic, cycloplegic (cyclopentolate 1%). Consider padding if very large. Daily review until healed. Watch for infection.

contact_lens_related.text: CONTACT LENS RELATED: High risk of Acanthamoeba/Pseudomonas. Stop lens wear. Corneal scraping if ulcerated. Intensive antibiotics. Urgent ophthalmology referral.

simple_abrasion.text: SIMPLE CORNEAL ABRASION: Topical antibiotic (chloramphenicol QDS), cycloplegic if painful. Usually heals in 24-48 hours. Follow-up if not improving.

corneal_ulcer.text: INFECTED CORNEAL ULCER: Corneal scraping for culture before antibiotics. Intensive topical antibiotics (hourly). Urgent ophthalmology referral. May need admission.

sterile_ulcer.text: STERILE CORNEAL ULCER: Topical antibiotics and lubricants. Investigate underlying cause (dry eye, autoimmune). Ophthalmology referral for assessment.

minor_irritation.text: MINOR IRRITATION: Artificial tears, lid hygiene. Consider dry eye syndrome. Routine follow-up if symptoms persist or worsen.

asymptomatic_finding.text: ASYMPTOMATIC FINDING: Document findings. Consider underlying pathology if unusual appearance. Routine ophthalmology referral for assessment.

recurrent_erosion.text: RECURRENT CORNEAL EROSION: Lubricating ointment at night, hypertonic saline drops. Ophthalmology referral for specialist management (may need debridement/laser).

investigate_cause.text: INVESTIGATE UNDERLYING CAUSE: Check for dry eye, blepharitis, trichiasis. Treat underlying condition. Ophthalmology referral if recurrent or severe.
